eng: He came on foot, across the downs, from Bramblehurst station, carrying in his thickly gloved hand a small black portmanteau.
fr: Il venait pedestrement, par la dune, de la station de Bramblehurst, portant, de sa main couverte d'un gant epais, une petite valise noire.

eng: He was wrapped up from head to foot, and the brim of his soft felt hat hid every inch of his face but the shiny tip of his nose; the snow had piled itself against his shoulders and chest, and added a white crest to the burden he carried.
fr: Il etait bien enveloppe des pieds a la tete, et le bord d'un chapeau de feutre mou ne laissait apercevoir de sa figure que le bout luisant de son nez. La neige s'etait amoncelee sur ses epaules, sur sa poitrine ; elle ajoutait aussi une crete blanche au sac dont il etait charge.

eng: He staggered into the "Coach and Horses" more dead than alive, and flung his portmanteau down. "A fire," he cried, "in the name of human charity! A room and a fire!"
fr: Il entra, chancelant, plus mort que vif, dans l'auberge et posant a terre son bagage : -- Du feu, s'ecria-t-il, du feu, par charite ! Une chambre et du feu !

eng: And with that much introduction, that and a couple of sovereigns flung upon the table, he took up his quarters in the inn.
fr: Sans autre preambule, et jetant deux souverains sur la table, il s'installa dans l'auberge.

eng: Mrs. Hall lit the fire and left him there while she went to prepare him a meal with her own hands.
fr: Madame Hall disposa le feu et alla preparer le repas de ses propres mains.

eng: A guest to stop at Iping in the wintertime was an unheard-of piece of luck, let alone a guest who was no "haggler,"
fr: Un hote s'arretant a Iping en hiver, c'etait une aubaine dont on n'avait jamais entendu parler.

eng: and she was resolved to show herself worthy of her good fortune.
fr: Elle etait resolue a se montrer digne de sa bonne fortune.

eng: As soon as the bacon was well under way, and Millie, her lymphatic maid, had been brisked up a bit by a few deftly chosen expressions of contempt,
fr: Des que le jambon fut bien a point, des que Millie, la lymphatique servante, eut ete un peu reveillee par quelques injures adroitement choisies,

eng: she carried the cloth, plates, and glasses into the parlour and began to lay them with the utmost _ clat_.
fr: l'hotesse apporta nappe, assiettes et verres dans la salle et commenca de mettre le couvert avec le plus d'elegance possible.

eng: Although the fire was burning up briskly, she was surprised to see that her visitor still wore his hat and coat, standing with his back to her and staring out of the window at the falling snow in the yard.
fr: Quoique le feu brulat vivement, elle constata, non sans surprise, que le voyageur conservait toujours son chapeau et son manteau, et se tenait de maniere a dissimuler son visage.

eng: His gloved hands were clasped behind him, and he seemed to be lost in thought.
fr: Ses mains toujours gantees etaient croisees derriere son dos. Il paraissait perdu dans ses reflexions.

eng: She noticed that the melting snow that still sprinkled his shoulders dripped upon her carpet.
fr: Elle remarqua que la neige fondue qui saupoudrait encore ses epaules, tombait goutte a goutte sur le tapis.

eng: "Can I take your hat and coat, sir?" she said, "and give them a good dry in the kitchen?"
fr: -- Voulez-vous me permettre, monsieur, dit-elle, de prendre vos effets, pour les mettre a secher dans la cuisine ?

eng: "No," he said without turning.
fr: - Non, repondit l'autre sans se retourner.

eng: She was not sure she had heard him, and was about to repeat her question.
fr: N'etant pas sure d'avoir bien entendu, elle allait repeter sa question, quand il retourna la tete et, la regardant :

eng: He turned his head and looked at her over his shoulder.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "I prefer to keep them on," he said with emphasis, and she noticed that he wore big blue spectacles with sidelights, and had a bush side-whisker over his coat-collar that completely hid his cheeks and face.
fr: -- Je prefere les garder, ajouta-t-il nettement. Madame Hall observa qu'il portait de grosses lunettes bleues, avec des verres a angle droit, et que d'epais favoris, repandus sur le col de son vetement, empechaient de rien voir de ses joues ni de son visage.

eng: "Very well, sir," she said. "_As_ you like. In a bit the room will be warmer."
fr: -- Tres bien, monsieur, comme il vous plaira... Dans un moment la piece sera plus chaude.

eng: He made no answer, and had turned his face away from her again, and Mrs. Hall, feeling that her conversational advances were ill-timed, laid the rest of the table things in a quick staccato and whisked out of the room.
fr: Il ne repliqua pas et se detourna de nouveau. Madame Hall, sentant ses avances inopportunes, acheva lestement de dresser la table et s'empressa, en trottinant, de sortir.

eng: Et encore un hote qui ne marchandait pas !
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: She put down the eggs and bacon with considerable emphasis, and called rather than said to him, "Your lunch is served, sir."
fr: Elle servit d'un geste important les oeufs au jambon et cria, plutot qu'elle ne dit : -- Votre dejeuner est pret, monsieur !

eng: "Thank you," he said at the same time, and did not stir until she was closing the door.
fr: -- Merci, fit-il aussitot. ~~~ Mais il ne bougea pas jusqu'a ce qu'elle eut referme la porte sur elle.

eng: Then he swung round and approached the table with a certain eager quickness.
fr: Alors seulement il fit volte-face et s'approcha de la table avec une certaine impatience.

eng: "That girl!" she said.
fr: 'cette fille ! s'ecria-t-elle.'

eng: "There! I clean forgot it."
fr: 'La ! j'ai tout a fait oublie la moutarde.'

eng: "It s her being so long!"
fr: 'C'est sa faute : pourquoi est-elle toujours si lente ?'

eng: And while she herself finished mixing the mustard, she gave Millie a few verbal stabs for her excessive slowness.
fr: 'Et, tout en achevant elle-meme de battre la moutarde, elle lanca vers Millie quelques amenites sur les inconvenients de l'indolence.'

eng: 'had only succeeded in delaying the mustard.'
fr: 'n'avait reussi qu'a l'empecher de servir la moutarde !'

eng: 'And him a new guest and wanting to stay!'
fr: 'Et cela, avec un nouvel hote, qui montrait l'intention de sejourner !'

eng: 'Then she filled the mustard pot, and, putting it with a certain stateliness upon a gold and black tea-tray, carried it into the parlour.'
fr: 'Alors l'hotesse remplit le moutardier et, le placant avec ceremonie sur le plateau a the, noir et or, elle le porta dans le salon.'

eng: 'She rapped and entered promptly.'
fr: 'Elle frappa et entra tout de suite.'

eng: 'As she did so her visitor moved quickly, so that she got but a glimpse of a white object disappearing behind the table.'
fr: 'Aussitot l'etranger fit un mouvement rapide : elle n'eut que le temps d'entrevoir un objet blanc qui disparaissait derriere la table ;'

eng: 'It would seem he was picking something from the floor.'
fr: 'le voyageur avait l'air de ramasser quelque chose sur le parquet.'

eng: 'She rapped down the mustard pot on the table, and then she noticed the overcoat and hat had been taken off and put over a chair in front of the fire, and a pair of wet boots threatened rust to her steel fender.'
fr: 'Ce n'est qu'apres avoir depose son plateau qu'elle remarqua que pardessus et chapeau avaient ete otes et places sur une chaise devant le feu. Une paire de souliers mouilles menacait de la rouille son garde-feu en acier.'

eng: 'She went to these things resolutely.'
fr: 'Elle s'avanca resolument vers cette defroque,'

eng: '"I suppose I may have them to dry now," she said in a voice that brooked no denial.'
fr: 'et, d'un ton qui n'admettait pas de refus : -- Maintenant, sans doute, je puis prendre tout cela pour le faire secher.'

eng: '"Leave the hat," said her visitor, in a muffled voice, and turning she saw he had raised his head and was sitting and looking at her.'
fr: '-- Laissez le chapeau ! >> repondit le visiteur d'une voix sourde. En se retournant, elle vit qu'il avait leve la tete et qu'il la regardait.'

eng: 'For a moment she stood gaping at him, too surprised to speak.'
fr: 'Pendant une minute, elle le considera fixement, trop surprise pour dire un mot.'

eng: It was the fact that all his forehead above his blue glasses was covered by a white bandage, and that another covered his ears, leaving not a scrap of his face exposed excepting only his pink, peaked nose.
fr: En effet, tout le front du voyageur, au-dessus des lunettes bleues, etait couvert d'un bandeau blanc ; un autre bandeau, applique sur les oreilles, ne laissait pas apercevoir le moindre bout de visage, si ce n'est un nez rouge et pointu, toujours aussi rouge et luisant que tout a l'heure, a l'arrivee.

eng: It was bright, pink, and shiny just as it had been at first.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He wore a dark-brown velvet jacket with a high, black, linen-lined collar turned up about his neck.
fr: L'homme portait une jaquette de velours fonce, avec un large collet noir, releve autour du cou et laissant passer une ligne de linge.

eng: The thick black hair, escaping as it could below and between the cross bandages, projected in curious tails and horns, giving him the strangest appearance conceivable.
fr: La chevelure, epaisse et brune, qui s'echappait au hasard, en petites queues, en petites cornes singulieres, de dessous les deux bandeaux croises, donnait a la physionomie l'aspect le plus etrange que l'on put imaginer.

eng: This muffled and bandaged head was so unlike what she had anticipated, that for a moment she was rigid.
fr: Cette tete, enveloppee, emmitouflee, etait si differente de ce qu'avait prevu madame Hall que celle-ci, pendant un moment, demeura petrifiee.

eng: He did not remove the serviette, but remained holding it, as she saw now, with a brown gloved hand, and regarding her with his inscrutable blue glasses.
fr: Lui, n'ecartait point sa serviette ; il continuait a la tenir sous son nez, ainsi qu'elle le voyait maintenant, d'une main gantee de marron, et, de ses verres impenetrables, il la regardait.

eng: "Leave the hat," he said, speaking very distinctly through the white cloth.
fr: -- Laissez le chapeau ! ~~~ repetait-il, parlant indistinctement a travers sa serviette blanche.

eng: Her nerves began to recover from the shock they had received.
fr: Les nerfs de madame Hall commencaient a se remettre de la secousse eprouvee.

eng: She placed the hat on the chair again by the fire.
fr: Elle laissa le chapeau sur la chaise aupres du feu.

eng: "I didn't know, sir," she began, "that..." and she stopped embarrassed.
fr: -- Je ne savais pas, monsieur, que... que... Et elle s'arreta, tout embarrassee.

eng: "Thank you," he said drily, glancing from her to the door and then at her again.
fr: -- Je vous remercie, fit-il sechement. Ses regards allaient alternativement d'elle a la porte.

eng: "I'll have them nicely dried, sir, at once," she said, and carried his clothes out of the room.
fr: -- Je vais les faire bien secher tout de suite >>, dit-elle en sortant de la piece avec les vetements.

eng: She glanced at his white-swathed head and blue goggles again as she was going out of the door; but his napkin was still in front of his face.
fr: Elle lanca un dernier coup d'oeil vers cette tete emmaillotee de blanc, vers ces lunettes sans expression ; la serviette cachait toujours la figure.

eng: She shivered a little as she closed the door behind her, and her face was eloquent of her surprise and perplexity.
fr: Elle frissonna un peu quand elle eut ferme la porte derriere elle, et son visage exprimait bien toute sa surprise, toute sa perplexite.

eng: "I never," she whispered.
fr: -- Non, jamais je n'ai..., dit-elle tout bas.

eng: "There!" She went quite softly to the kitchen, and was too preoccupied to ask Millie what she was messing about with now, when she got there.
fr: Elle retourna tout doucement a la cuisine, trop preoccupee pour demander a Millie ce que celle-ci fricotait juste a ce moment.

eng: The visitor sat and listened to her retreating feet.
fr: Le voyageur s'assit et tendit l'oreille au bruit des pas qui s'eloignaient.

eng: "What a turn them bandages did give me, to be sure!"
fr: 'Mon Dieu, quelle peur il m'a faite, avec tous ses bandeaux !'

eng: She put on some more coal, unfolded the clothes-horse, and extended the traveller s coat upon this.
fr: Elle raviva le feu, ouvrit un chevalet et etendit dessus les vetements de son hote.

eng: "And they goggles! Why, he looked more like a divin helmet than a human man!"
fr: 'Et ces lunettes !... A coup sur, il avait l'air d'un scaphandrier plutot que d'un homme ordinaire !'

eng: She hung his muffler on a corner of the horse.
fr: Elle pendit le cache-nez a un coin du support.

eng: "And holding that handkerchief over his mouth all the time. Talkin through it! ... Perhaps his mouth was hurt too maybe."
fr: 'Et il tient tout le temps ce mouchoir sur sa bouche ! Il parle a travers... Peut-etre aussi a-t-il quelque chose a la bouche. Qui sait ?'

eng: She turned round, as one who suddenly remembers.
fr: Elle tourna sur elle-meme, comme frappee d'un brusque souvenir :

eng: "Bless my soul alive!" she said, going off at a tangent; "ain t you done them taters _yet_, Millie?"
fr: '-- Que Dieu me benisse ! s'ecria-t-elle en changeant subitement de sujet. N'avez-vous pas encore fait ces pommes de terre, Millie ?'

eng: When Mrs. Hall went to clear away the stranger s lunch, her idea that his mouth must also have been cut or disfigured in the accident she supposed him to have suffered, was confirmed,
fr: Lorsque madame Hall vint pour desservir le dejeuner de l'etranger, elle fut confirmee dans son idee qu'il devait avoir eu la bouche blessee et deformee par un accident.

eng: for he was smoking a pipe, and all the time that she was in the room he never loosened the silk muffler he had wrapped round the lower part of his face to put the mouthpiece to his lips.
fr: En effet, il fumait une pipe et, pendant tout le temps qu'elle resta dans la piece, il ne se separa point, pour porter le tuyau a ses levres, du foulard de soie dont il avait enveloppe la partie inferieure de sa figure.

eng: "There is no speedier delivery?"
fr: N'est-il pas possible d'avoir cela plus rapidement ?

eng: he said.
fr: dit-il.

eng: and seemed quite disappointed when she answered, "No."
fr: Il parut contrarie quand elle lui repondit que non.

eng: Was she quite sure?
fr: En etait-elle bien sure ?

eng: No man with a trap who would go over?
fr: N'y avait-il pas un homme qui voulut y aller avec une charrette ?...

eng: Mrs. Hall, nothing loath, answered his questions and developed a conversation.
fr: Madame Hall, sans hesiter, lui expliqua les difficultes du pays, et la conversation s'engagea.

eng: 'There was my sister s son, Tom, jest cut his arm with a scythe, tumbled on it in the ayfield, and, bless me! he was three months tied up sir.'
fr: 'Tenez, mon neveu, Tom, il s'est coupe au bras, en jouant avec une faux, en tombant dessus dans un champ ou l'on faisait les foins. Dieu me pardonne, il est reste trois mois, monsieur, sans pouvoir rien faire.'

eng: 'You d hardly believe it.'
fr: 'C'est a ne pas le croire :'

eng: 'It s regular given me a dread of a scythe, sir." "I can quite understand that," said the visitor.'
fr: 'j'ai toujours, depuis lors, grand-peur des faux. - Je comprends cela !'

eng: '"He was afraid, one time, that he d have to have an op ration he was that bad, sir." '
fr: 'Nous avons craint, une fois, qu'il n'eut a subir une operation. Il etait si mal, monsieur !'

eng: 'The visitor laughed abruptly, a bark of a laugh that he seemed to bite and kill in his mouth.'
fr: 'Le visiteur eclata brusquement d'un rire qu'il parut reprimer et etouffer dans sa bouche. -- Ah !'

eng: "He was, sir. And no laughing matter to them as had the doing for him, as I had my sister being took up with her little ones so much."
fr: '- Oui, monsieur. Et il n'y avait pas de quoi rire, occupee de lui comme je l'etais, parce que ma soeur avait assez de besogne avec son petit monde.'

eng: "There was bandages to do, sir, and bandages to undo."
fr: 'Il y avait des pansements a faire, a defaire.'

eng: "So that if I may make so bold as to say it, sir "
fr: 'En sorte que, si j'osais le dire, monsieur...'

eng: ""Will you get me some matches?" said the visitor, quite abruptly. "My pipe is out.""
fr: '- Voulez-vous me donner des allumettes ? fit brusquement l'etranger. Ma pipe est eteinte.'

eng: "Mrs. Hall was pulled up suddenly."
fr: 'Madame Hall fut arretee net.'

eng: "It was certainly rude of him, after telling him all she had done."
fr: 'Cela etait vraiment malhonnete de la part de ce monsieur, apres qu'elle venait de lui dire tout ce qu'elle avait eu d'ennuis !...'

eng: "She gasped at him for a moment, and remembered the two sovereigns."
fr: 'Elle le devisagea un moment, interloquee ; puis elle se rappela les deux souverains donnes a l'arrivee, et cela fit qu'elle alla chercher des allumettes.'

eng: "She went for the matches."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: ""Thanks," he said concisely, as she put them down, and turned his shoulder upon her and stared out of the window again."
fr: '-- Merci ! fit-il, quand elle lui en apporta. Et il se detourna pour regarder de nouveau par la fenetre.'

eng: "It was altogether too discouraging."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Evidently he was sensitive on the topic of operations and bandages."
fr: 'Evidemment il etait chatouilleux sur la question des operations et des pansements.'

eng: "She did not "make so bold as to say," however, after all."
fr: 'Elle n'osa plus rien dire,'

eng: "But his snubbing way had irritated her, and Millie had a hot time of it that afternoon."
fr: 'mais cette maniere de la rudoyer l'avait irritee... Millie eut lieu de s'en apercevoir pendant l'apres-midi.'

eng: "The visitor remained in the parlour until four o clock, without giving the ghost of an excuse for an intrusion."
fr: 'Le voyageur resta dans le salon jusqu'a quatre heures, sans donner a son hotesse pretexte a y entrer ;'

eng: "For the most part he was quite still during that time; it would seem he sat in the growing darkness smoking in the firelight perhaps dozing."
fr: 'il demeura presque continuellement immobile, sans doute assis, dans l'obscurite croissante, fumant a la lueur du foyer, ou peut-etre sommeillant.'

eng: Her visitor, she saw as she opened the door, was seated in the armchair before the fire, dozing it would seem, with his bandaged head drooping on one side.
fr: Son hote - elle le vit en entrant - etait assis dans le fauteuil devant le feu, assoupi a ce qu'il semblait ; sa tete emmaillotee s'inclinait de cote.

eng: The only light in the room was the red glow from the fire which lit his eyes like adverse railway signals, but left his downcast face in darkness and the scanty vestiges of the day that came in through the open door.
fr: Pour toute lumiere dans la chambre, la lueur rougeatre qui venait du foyer.

eng: Everything was ruddy, shadowy, and indistinct to her, the more so since she had just been lighting the bar lamp, and her eyes were dazzled.
fr: Tout etait ou violemment eclaire ou tout a fait sombre. Elle avait d'autant plus de peine a rien distinguer qu'elle venait precisement d'allumer la lampe du bar et que ses yeux etaient encore eblouis.

eng: The shadows, she fancied, had tricked her.
fr: L'obscurite, pensa-t-elle, l'avait trompee.

eng: "Would you mind, sir, this man a-coming to look at the clock, sir?" she said, recovering from the momentary shock.
fr: Est-ce que vous voudriez bien permettre que monsieur vienne arranger l'horloge ? dit-elle en surmontant son trouble.

eng: "Look at the clock?" he said, staring round in a drowsy manner, and speaking over his hand, and then, getting more fully awake, "certainly."
fr: Arranger l'horloge ? repeta le voyageur, jetant autour de lui des regards endormis et parlant par-dessus sa main ; puis, tout a fait reveille : -- Mais, certainement !...

eng: Then came the light, and Mr. Teddy Henfrey, entering, was confronted by this bandaged person.
fr: Alors, la piece eclairee, M. Teddy Henfrey se trouva face a face avec l'homme aux bandeaux.

eng: He was, he says, "taken aback."
fr: Il en fut, disait-il, << tout chose >>.

eng: "Good afternoon," said the stranger, regarding him as Mr. Henfrey says, with a vivid sense of the dark spectacles "like a lobster."
fr: -- Bonjour ! ~~~ lui dit l'etranger, en le fixant << avec des yeux de langouste >>, selon l'expression pittoresque de M. Henfrey qui designait ainsi les lunettes aux verres fumes.

eng: "I hope," said Mr. Henfrey, "that it s no intrusion."
fr: -- J'espere, dit celui-ci, que je ne vous gene pas.

eng: "None whatever," said the stranger.
fr: -- Non, pas du tout, repondit l'etranger.

eng: "Though, I understand," he said turning to Mrs. Hall, "that this room is really to be mine for my own private use."
fr: Pourtant, j'entends - et il se tournait vers madame Hall - que cette piece soit bien a moi, pour mon usage particulier.

eng: "I thought, sir," said Mrs. Hall, "you d prefer the clock..."
fr: -- Je pensais, monsieur, que vous prefereriez que l'horloge...

eng: "Certainly," said the stranger, "certainly but, as a rule, I like to be alone and undisturbed."
fr: -- Certainement, certainement... Mais, regle generale, je desire etre seul et que l'on ne me derange pas.

eng: "But I m really glad to have the clock seen to," he said, seeing a certain hesitation in Mr. Henfrey s manner.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "Very glad."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Mr. Henfrey had intended to apologise and withdraw, but this anticipation reassured him.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The stranger turned round with his back to the fireplace and put his hands behind his back.
fr: Il fit volte-face, les epaules a la cheminee, les mains derriere son dos.

eng: "And presently," he said, "when the clock-mending is over, I think I should like to have some tea. But not till the clock-mending is over."
fr: -- Et maintenant, ajouta-t-il, quand la reparation sera faite, je voudrais avoir du the... Mais pas avant que la reparation soit terminee.

eng: Mrs. Hall was about to leave the room she made no conversational advances this time, because she did not want to be snubbed in front of Mr. Henfrey when her visitor asked her if she had made any arrangements about his boxes at Bramblehurst.
fr: Madame Hall etait sur le point de sortir -- cette fois, elle n'essaya pas d'engager la conversation, pour ne pas s'exposer a etre rabrouee devant M. Henfrey -- lorsque le client lui demanda si elle avait pris ses dispositions au sujet des malles restees a Bramblehurst.

eng: She told him she had mentioned the matter to the postman, and that the carrier could bring them over on the morrow.
fr: Elle repondit qu'elle avait parle au facteur et que le voiturier les apporterait le lendemain.

eng: "You are certain that is the earliest?" he said.
fr: -- Etes-vous sure que ce soit le moyen le plus rapide ?

eng: She was certain, with a marked coldness.
fr: Elle en etait sure, elle l'affirma avec froideur.

eng: "I should explain," he added, "what I was really too cold and fatigued to do before, that I am an experimental investigator."
fr: -- C'est que, voyez-vous... ~~~ Je vais vous expliquer ce que je n'ai pu vous dire plus tot parce que j'etais trop gele et trop fatigue : je suis un travailleur, un homme de laboratoire...

eng: "Indeed, sir," said Mrs. Hall, much impressed.
fr: -- Ah ! vraiment, monsieur ! ~~~ fit madame Hall, tres interessee.

eng: I do not wish to be disturbed in my work.
fr: Je tiens a n'etre pas trouble dans mon travail.

eng: In addition to my work, an accident " "I thought as much," said Mrs. Hall to herself. " necessitates a certain retirement.
fr: En plus, d'ailleurs, de mon travail, un accident qui m'est arrive... (<< Je le pensais bien ! >> se dit madame Hall)... exige une certaine retraite.

eng: My eyes are sometimes so weak and painful that I have to shut myself up in the dark for hours together.
fr: Mes yeux sont quelquefois si affaiblis et si douloureux que je dois m'enfermer dans l'obscurite des heures entieres, m'enfermer a clef.

eng: Lock myself up.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: At such times the slightest disturbance, the entry of a stranger into the room, is a source of excruciating annoyance to me.
fr: A ces moments-la, le moindre derangement, par exemple l'entree de quelqu'un dans ma chambre, est pour moi une cause de veritable torture...

eng: it is well these things should be understood.
fr: Il est bon que cela soit entendu.

eng: "Certainly, sir," said Mrs. Hall.
fr: -- Parfaitement, monsieur.

eng: "And if I might make so bold as to ask..."
fr: Si j'osais me permettre de demander...

eng: "That I think, is all," said the stranger, with that quietly irresistible air of finality he could assume at will.
fr: C'est bien tout, je crois, -- dit l'etranger, de ce ton tranquille et sans replique qu'il savait prendre pour couper court aux interrogations.

eng: Mrs. Hall reserved her question and sympathy for a better occasion.
fr: Madame Hall dut garder sa question et sa pitie pour une circonstance meilleure.

eng: After Mrs. Hall had left the room, he remained standing in front of the fire, glaring, so Mr. Henfrey puts it, at the clock-mending.
fr: Quand elle eut quitte la piece, il resta debout devant le foyer, attentif - M. Henfrey le rapporta - a la reparation de l'horloge.

eng: Mr. Henfrey not only took off the hands of the clock, and the face, but extracted the works; and he tried to work in as slow and quiet and unassuming a manner as possible.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He worked with the lamp close to him, and the green shade threw a brilliant light upon his hands, and upon the frame and wheels, and left the rest of the room shadowy.
fr: M. Henfrey travaillait, une lampe posee tout pres de lui : l'abat-jour vert jetait une lumiere plus vive sur ses mains, sur le cadran et sur les petites roues de l'horloge, laissant dans l'ombre le reste du salon.

eng: So still, it got on Henfrey's nerves.
fr: Si bien immobile que cela finit par agacer Henfrey.

eng: He felt alone in the room and looked up, and there, grey and dim, was the bandaged head and huge blue lenses staring fixedly, with a mist of green spots drifting in front of them.
fr: Il eut l'impression d'etre seul et regarda : grise et peu eclairee, se dressait l'enorme tete a bandeaux, qui l'examinait avec ses grosses lunettes sombres, obscurcies d'une buee verdatre.

eng: It was so uncanny to Henfrey that for a minute they remained staring blankly at one another.
fr: Cela devint pour Henfrey si insupportable que, pendant une minute, ils demeurerent tous deux a se considerer d'un air confus.

eng: He looked up as if to take aim with that introductory shot.
fr: Il se redressa comme pour choisir l'instant de placer cette remarque.

eng: "The weather..." he began.
fr: -- Le temps..., commenca-t-il.

eng: "Why don't you finish and go?" said the rigid figure, evidently in a state of painfully suppressed rage.
fr: -- Pourquoi ne terminez-vous pas et ne partez-vous pas ? dit la figure rigide, evidemment en proie a une fureur difficilement contenue.

eng: "All you've got to do is to fix the hour-hand on its axle. You're simply humbugging..."
fr: -- Tout ce que vous etes parvenu a faire, c'est de resserrer l'aiguille sur le cadran. Vous vous moquez du monde !

eng: "Certainly, sir... one minute more. I overlooked..."
fr: -- Bien, monsieur... Une seule minute encore. Je revoyais avec soin...

eng: and Mr. Henfrey finished and went.
fr: M. Henfrey finit sa besogne et s'en alla.

eng: But he went feeling excessively annoyed.
fr: Mais il s'en alla extremement contrarie.

eng: "Can t a man look at you? Ugly!"
fr: ">> Puis : << Un homme n'a-t-il donc pas le droit de vous regarder ? Vilain singe ! >>"

eng: "Seemingly not."
fr: ">> Et encore : << Non, a ce qu'il parait..."

eng: Hall had evidently been "stopping a bit" at Sidderbridge, to judge by his driving.
fr: A n'en pas douter, << il s'etait arrete un brin >> a Sidderbridge : il suffisait, pour en etre sur, de le voir conduire.

eng: "Ow do, Teddy?" he said, passing.
fr: -- Comment va, Teddy ? demanda-t-il en passant.

eng: "You got a rum un up home!" said Teddy.
fr: Ah ! ~~~ vous avez chez vous un drole de corps !

eng: Hall very sociably pulled up.
fr: Hall, sans se faire prier, arreta son cheval.

eng: "What s that?" he asked.
fr: -- Quoi donc ?

eng: "Rum-looking customer stopping at the Coach and Horses," said Teddy.
fr: -- Un client qui a l'air bien original est descendu chez vous, mon vieux !...

eng: "My sakes!"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: And he proceeded to give Hall a vivid description of his grotesque guest.
fr: Et Teddy commenca de faire a Hall une description pittoresque de l'hote bizarre de sa femme.

eng: "Looks a bit like a disguise, don t it? I d like to see a man s face if I had him stopping in _my_ place," said Henfrey.
fr: -- Il a un peu l'air d'un deguise. Moi, je tiendrais a voir la figure d'un homme si j'avais a le loger dans mon etablissement.

eng: "But women are that trustful where strangers are concerned. He s took your rooms and he ain t even given a name, Hall."
fr: Mais les femmes sont si pleines de confiance, des qu'il s'agit d'etrangers ! Hall, il s'est installe chez vous, et il n'a meme pas encore donne de nom !

eng: 'said Hall, who was a man of sluggish apprehension.'
fr: 'repondit Hall, qui avait l'intelligence plutot paresseuse.'

eng: '"Yes," said Teddy.'
fr: 'Parfaitement ! reprit Teddy.'

eng: '"By the week. ~~~ Whatever he is, you can t get rid of him under the week.'
fr: 'Il a loue a la semaine, et vous ne serez pas debarrasse de lui avant huit jours.'

eng: Altogether he left Hall vaguely suspicious.
fr: Bref, il laissa Hall vaguement inquiet.

eng: "Get up, old girl," said Hall. "I s pose I must see bout this."
fr: Hue, donc ! ~~~ fit celui-ci. Il faut que j'y aille voir.

eng: Teddy trudged on his way with his mind considerably relieved.
fr: Teddy poursuivit sa route, l'esprit tout a fait soulage.

eng: Instead of "seeing bout it," however, Hall on his return was severely rated by his wife on the length of time he had spent in Sidderbridge, and his mild inquiries were answered snappishly and in a manner not to the point.
fr: Au lieu << d'y aller voir >>, Hall, a son retour chez lui, fut severement attrape par sa femme pour le temps qu'il avait passe a Sidderbridge ; ses questions timides furent accueillies avec aigreur, sans qu'elle repondit a l'objet de ses preoccupations.

eng: But the seed of suspicion Teddy had sown germinated in the mind of Mr. Hall in spite of these discouragements.
fr: Mais, en depit des rebuffades, la graine de mefiance semee par Teddy germait dans sa cervelle.

eng: "You wim don t know everything," said Mr. Hall, resolved to ascertain more about the personality of his guest at the earliest possible opportunity.
fr: Vous ne savez pas tout, vous autres femmes ! dit M. ~~~ Hall, resolu a etre renseigne le plus tot possible sur la qualite de son hote.

eng: And after the stranger had gone to bed, which he did about half-past nine, Mr. Hall went very aggressively into the parlour and looked very hard at his wife s furniture, just to show that the stranger wasn t master there, and scrutinised closely and a little contemptuously a sheet of mathematical computations the stranger had left.
fr: Des que l'etranger fut couche, vers neuf heures et demie, M. Hall entra, l'air agressif, dans le salon, et il examina d'un oeil soupconneux le mobilier de sa femme, pour bien affirmer que l'etranger n'etait pas maitre dans la place ; il reluqua, non sans un peu de mepris, une feuille d'operations mathematiques oubliee par l'autre.

eng: When retiring for the night he instructed Mrs. Hall to look very closely at the stranger s luggage when it came next day.
fr: En se retirant, il recommanda a madame Hall de veiller de tres pres aux bagages, quand ils arriveraient le lendemain.

eng: "You mind your own business, Hall," said Mrs. Hall, "and I ll mind mine."
fr: Occupez-vous de vos affaires, Hall ! ~~~ repliqua celle-ci ; moi, je m'occuperai des miennes.

eng: '"Whup!" cried Hall, jumping back, for he was no hero with dogs,'
fr: '-- Oust ! cria Hall, en reculant, car il n'etait pas brave.'

eng: 'and Fearenside howled, "Lie down!" and snatched his whip.'
fr: 'Fearenside hurla : -- Allez coucher ! -- et prit son fouet.'

eng: 'They saw the dog s teeth had slipped the hand, heard a kick, saw the dog execute a flanking jump and get home on the stranger s leg, and heard the rip of his trousering.'
fr: 'Tous deux virent les dents du chien effleurer la main, la bete executer un saut de cote et saisir la jambe de l'etranger : le pantalon se dechira, avec un bruit sec.'

eng: 'Then the finer end of Fearenside s whip reached his property, and the dog, yelping with dismay, retreated under the wheels of the waggon.'
fr: 'Alors, la fine pointe du fouet de Fearenside atteignit le coupable, et celui-ci, aboyant de peur, se refugia sous la voiture.'

eng: 'It was all the business of a swift half-minute.'
fr: 'Cela fut l'affaire d'une demi-minute.'

eng: 'No one spoke, everyone shouted.'
fr: 'Personne n'avait parle, tout le monde avait crie.'

eng: "You brute, you!" said Fearenside, climbing off the waggon with his whip in his hand,
fr: '-- Ah ! ~~~ la sale bete ! -- fit Fearenside, sautant de la voiture avec son fouet a la main,

eng: while the dog watched him through the wheel.
fr: tandis que le chien, sous la voiture, le suivait du regard.

eng: "Come here," said Fearenside "You d better."
"He wuz bit," said Hall.
fr: '-- Il aura ete mordu, dit-il.

eng: "I d better go and see to en," and he trotted after the stranger.
fr: Je ferais bien d'y aller moi-meme. Il suivit l'etranger.

eng: He met Mrs. Hall in the passage.
fr: Dans le couloir il rencontra madame Hall et lui apprit le mefait du chien.

eng: "Carrier s darg," he said "bit en."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He went straight upstairs,
fr: Il monta rapidement l'escalier.

eng: and the stranger s door being ajar, he pushed it open and was entering without any ceremony,
fr: La porte du voyageur etant entre-baillee, il la poussa, l'ouvrit et entra sans ceremonie :

eng: being of a naturally sympathetic turn of mind.
fr: la nature l'avait fait d'humeur familiere.

eng: It was so rapid that it gave him no time to observe.
fr: Tout cela fut si rapide qu'il ne put rien distinguer : des formes vagues en mouvement, une poussee, un choc, rien de plus.

eng: A waving of indecipherable shapes, a blow, and a concussion.
fr: des formes vagues en mouvement, une poussee, un choc, rien de plus.

eng: There he stood on the dark little landing, wondering what it might be that he had seen.
fr: Il resta abasourdi sur le palier obscur, se demandant avec terreur ce qui s'etait passe.

eng: A couple of minutes after, he rejoined the little group that had formed outside the "Coach and Horses."
fr: Deux minutes, et il rejoignit le petit groupe qui s'etait reuni devant la maison.

eng: There was Fearenside telling about it all over again for the second time;
fr: Il y avait la Fearenside racontant pour la seconde fois l'incident du chien ;

eng: there was Mrs. Hall saying his dog didn t have no business to bite her guests;
fr: il y avait la madame Hall disant que ce chien ne mordait jamais les voyageurs ;

eng: there was Huxter, the general dealer from over the road, interrogative;
fr: il y avait la, en curieux, Huxter, le boutiquier d'en face,

eng: and Sandy Wadgers from the forge, judicial;
fr: et, en arbitre, Sandy Wadgers, qui venait de sa forge ;

eng: besides women and children, all of them saying fatuities:
fr: puis des femmes et des enfants, tous parlant a tort et a travers.

eng: "Wouldn t let en bite _me_, I knows";
fr: -- Je ne me laisserais pas mordre, moi, je vous en reponds !

eng: "Tasn t right _have_ such dargs";
fr: -- Il devrait etre defendu d'avoir de pareils animaux.

eng: "Whad _e_ bite n for, then?"
fr: -- Pourquoi l'a-t-il mordu ?

eng: Besides, his vocabulary was altogether too limited to express his impressions.
fr: D'ailleurs, son vocabulaire etait trop limite pour lui permettre de traduire ses impressions.

eng: "He don't want no help, he says," he said in answer to his wife's inquiry.
fr: Il pretend n'avoir besoin de personne, -- repondit-il a une question de sa femme.

eng: "We'd better be a-takin' of his luggage in."
fr: Il vaudrait mieux rentrer ses bagages a l'interieur.

eng: "He ought to have it cauterised at once," said Mr. Huxter; "especially if it's at all inflamed."
fr: Il aurait du cauteriser la plaie immediatement, prononca M. Huxter, surtout si elle est a vif.

eng: "I'd shoot en, that's what I'd do," said a lady in the group.
fr: Moi, je tuerais la bete, voila ce que je ferais ! dit une femme, dans le groupe.

eng: Suddenly the dog began growling again.
fr: Tout a coup le chien se mit a grogner de nouveau.

eng: "Come along," cried an angry voice in the doorway, and there stood the muffled stranger with his collar turned up, and his hat-brim bent down.
fr: Venez donc, allons ! cria sous la porte une voix courroucee. L'inconnu etait la, bien enveloppe, le col releve, le bord du chapeau rabattu sur les yeux.

eng: "The sooner you get those things in the better I'll be pleased."
fr: Plus vite vous aurez rentre tout cela, plus je serai content.

eng: It is stated by an anonymous bystander that his trousers and gloves had been changed.
fr: Il est etabli par le temoignage universel qu'il avait change de pantalon et de gants.

eng: "Was you hurt, sir?" said Fearenside.
fr: Etes-vous blesse, monsieur ? demanda Fearenside.

eng: "I'm rare sorry the darg"
fr: Je suis tout a fait desole que cet animal...

eng: "Not a bit," said the stranger. "Never broke the skin. Hurry up with those things."
fr: Non, pas du tout. Il ne m'a pas entame la peau. Allons, vite, depechez-vous.

eng: He then swore to himself, so Mr. Hall asserts.
fr: Puis, il grommela quelque chose, affirma M. Hall.

eng: Directly the first crate was, in accordance with his directions, carried into the parlour, the stranger flung himself upon it with extraordinary eagerness, and began to unpack it, scattering the straw with an utter disregard of Mrs. Hall's carpet.
fr: Des que la premiere manne eut ete, conformement a ses ordres, apportee dans le salon, l'etranger se jeta dessus avec une ardeur incroyable et en commenca le deballage, eparpillant la paille, sans egard pour le tapis de madame Hall.

eng: And from it he began to produce bottles little fat bottles containing powders, small and slender bottles containing coloured and white fluids, fluted blue bottles labeled Poison, bottles with round bodies and slender necks, large green-glass bottles, large white-glass bottles, bottles with glass stoppers and frosted labels, bottles with fine corks, bottles with bungs, bottles with wooden caps, wine bottles, salad-oil bottles putting them in rows on the chiffonnier, on the mantel, on the table under the window, round the floor, on the bookshelf everywhere.
fr: Il en tira des bouteilles, des bouteilles petites et ventrues contenant des poudres ; des bouteilles petites et longues contenant des liquides colores ou incolores ; des bouteilles cannelees, en verre bleu, etiquetees : poison ; des bouteilles a panse ronde et a col elance ; d'enormes bouteilles en verre bleu, d'enormes bouteilles en verre blanc ; des bouteilles avec des bouchons de cristal et des etiquettes, des bouteilles avec des bouchons de liege, des bouteilles avec des bondes, des bouteilles a chape de bois, des bouteilles a vin, des bouteilles a huile, etc., etc. Il les mettait en rangs sur le chiffonnier, sur la cheminee, sur la table devant la fenetre, sur le parquet, sur les rayons a livres, partout, partout.

eng: The chemist's shop in Bramblehurst could not boast half so many. Quite a sight it was.
fr: Le pharmacien de Bramblehurst n'aurait pu se vanter d'en posseder autant dans sa boutique. C'etait une vraie curiosite.

eng: Crate after crate yielded bottles, until all six were empty and the table high with straw;
fr: Les mannes, les unes apres les autres, produisaient toujours des bouteilles. Enfin, quand tout cela fut vide, la paille d'emballage montait a la hauteur de la table.

eng: the only things that came out of these crates besides the bottles were a number of test-tubes and a carefully packed balance.
fr: Les seules choses qui sortirent de la, avec des bouteilles, ce furent un grand nombre d'eprouvettes, de tubes, et une balance soigneusement empaquetee.

eng: When Mrs. Hall took his dinner in to him, he was already so absorbed in his work, pouring little drops out of the bottles into test-tubes, that he did not hear her until she had swept away the bulk of the straw and put the tray on the table, with some little emphasis perhaps, seeing the state that the floor was in.
fr: Quand madame Hall lui apporta son diner, il etait deja absorbe par son travail et occupe a verser dans des tubes quelques gouttes de ses bouteilles ; il l'entendit seulement apres qu'elle eut balaye le plus gros et pose le plateau sur la table, non peut-etre sans quelque mauvaise humeur causee par l'etat dans lequel elle voyait son plancher.

eng: Then he half turned his head and immediately turned it away again.
fr: A ce moment, il remua la tete, et tout aussitot se retourna.

eng: But she saw he had removed his glasses; they were beside him on the table, and it seemed to her that his eye sockets were extraordinarily hollow.
fr: Elle vit du moins qu'il avait ote ses lunettes ; elles etaient a cote de lui sur la table : il lui sembla que ses orbites etaient singulierement creuses.

eng: He put on his spectacles again, and then turned and faced her.
fr: Il reprit ses verres, pivota et lui fit face.

eng: She was about to complain of the straw on the floor when he anticipated her.
fr: Elle allait se plaindre de la paille qui jonchait le plancher lorsqu'il la devanca :

eng: "I wish you wouldn t come in without knocking," he said in the tone of abnormal exasperation that seemed so characteristic of him.
fr: -- Je vous prie de ne jamais entrer sans frapper ! -- lui dit-il avec une exasperation anormale qui paraissait chez lui caracteristique.

eng: "I knocked, but seemingly "
fr: -- J'ai frappe... Probablement que...

eng: "Perhaps you did. But in my investigations my really very urgent and necessary investigations the slightest disturbance, the jar of a door I must ask you "
fr: -- Peut-etre bien. Mais, dans mes recherches, des recherches vraiment tres urgentes et tres importantes, le plus leger trouble, le bruit d'une porte... je suis oblige de vous demander...

eng: "Certainly, sir. You can turn the lock if you re like that, you know. Any time."
fr: -- Parfaitement, monsieur !... S'il en est ainsi vous pouvez fermer a clef, n'est-ce pas ? Quelquefois...

eng: "A very good idea," said the stranger.
fr: -- Bonne idee, repliqua l'etranger.

eng: "This stror, sir, if I might make so bold as to remark "
fr: -- Cette paille... si j'osais faire observer...

eng: "Don t. If the straw makes trouble put it down in the bill."
fr: -- Inutile.

eng: And he mumbled at her words suspiciously like curses.
fr: Si cette paille vous gene, portez-la sur la note. Et il murmura quelque chose entre ses dents, -- des mots suspects, comme des maledictions.

eng: He was so odd, standing there, so aggressive and explosive, bottle in one hand and test-tube in the other, that Mrs. Hall was quite alarmed.
fr: Il etait la, debout, si bizarre, si agressif, une bouteille dans une main, un tube dans l'autre, que madame Hall eut une sorte d'inquietude.

eng: But she was a resolute woman.
fr: Mais c'etait une femme resolue.

eng: "In which case, I should like to know, sir, what you consider "
fr: -- En ce cas, je desirerais savoir, monsieur, a combien vous estimez...

eng: "A shilling put down a shilling. Surely a shilling s enough?"
fr: -- Un shilling, mettez un shilling... C'est assez, n'est-ce pas, un shilling ?

eng: "So be it," said Mrs. Hall, taking up the table-cloth and beginning to spread it over the table. "If you re satisfied, of course "
fr: -- Soit ! ~~~ dit madame Hall, prenant la nappe et commencant a l'etendre sur la table.

eng: He turned and sat down, with his coat-collar toward her.
fr: Il s'assit, le dos tourne, ne montrant plus que le col de son paletot.

eng: All the afternoon he worked with the door locked and, as Mrs. Hall testifies, for the most part in silence.
fr: Il travailla jusqu'au soir, la porte fermee a clef, et, ainsi qu'en temoigna madame Hall, silencieusement, presque tout le temps.

eng: But once there was a concussion and a sound of bottles ringing together as though the table had been hit, and the smash of a bottle flung violently down, and then a rapid pacing athwart the room.
fr: Une fois pourtant, il y eut un choc de bouteilles heurtees les unes contre les autres, comme si la table avait ete bousculee, suivi d'un fracas de verre brise sur le plancher ; puis, des pas a travers la chambre.

eng: Fearing "something was the matter," she went to the door and listened, not caring to knock.
fr: Craignant quelque malheur, madame Hall vint ecouter a la porte, sans oser frapper.

eng: "I can t go on," he was raving. "I _can t_ go on. Three hundred thousand, four hundred thousand! The huge multitude! Cheated! All my life it may take me! ... Patience! Patience indeed! ... Fool! fool!"
fr: -- Je ne peux pas continuer ! repetait-il avec desespoir. Non, je ne peux pas continuer !... Trois cent mille ! Quatre cent mille ! C'est l'infini !... Vole !... Cela peut me prendre toute ma vie... Patience ! patience donc, insense ! insense !

eng: When she took in his tea she saw broken glass in the corner of the room under the concave mirror, and a golden stain that had been carelessly wiped.
fr: En lui apportant le the, elle vit des eclats de verre dans un coin, sous le miroir a barbe, et une tache doree qui avait ete sommairement essuyee.

eng: She called attention to it.
fr: Elle la fit remarquer.

eng: "Put it down in the bill," snapped her visitor. "For God s sake don t worry me. If there s damage done, put it down in the bill,"
fr: -- Portez-la sur la note ! repondit aigrement le voyageur. Pour l'amour de Dieu, ne m'ennuyez point ! S'il y a quelque degat, vous l'ajouterez sur la note.

eng: and he went on ticking a list in the exercise book before him.
fr: Et il se remit a consulter une liste dans le cahier ouvert devant lui.

eng: "I ll tell you something," said Fearenside, mysteriously.
fr: -- Je vais vous dire une chose !... annonca Fearenside d'un petit air mysterieux.

eng: It was late in the afternoon, and they were in the little beer-shop of Iping Hanger.
fr: L'apres-midi s'avancait et l'on se trouvait dans le petit debit de biere d'Iping.

eng: "Well?" said Teddy Henfrey.
fr: -- Hein ? fit Teddy Henfrey.

eng: "This chap you re speaking of, what my dog bit. Well he s black. Leastways, his legs are. I seed through the tear of his trousers and the tear of his glove. You d have expected a sort of pinky to show, wouldn t you? Well there wasn t none. Just blackness.'
fr: -- Ce gaillard dont vous me parlez, que mon chien a mordu... eh bien ! c'est un negre. Du moins, ses jambes sont noires. J'ai vu cela a travers la dechirure de son pantalon, comme a travers la dechirure de son gant. Vous vous seriez attendu, n'est-ce pas, a voir quelque chose de rose ? Eh bien, pas du tout ! Tout a fait noir !

eng: "My sakes!" said Henfrey.
fr: '-- Parbleu ! s'ecria Henfrey,

eng: "It s a rummy case altogether. Why, his nose is as pink as paint!"
fr: c'est un cas etrange, tout de meme ! Pourquoi donc son nez est-il aussi rose que s'il etait peint ?

eng: "That s true," said Fearenside.
fr: '-- C'est exact, repliqua Fearenside ;

eng: "I knows that.
fr: je le reconnais.

eng: And I tell ee what I m thinking. That marn s a piebald, Teddy.
fr: Mais je dis ce que je pense : cet homme est un homme pie, Teddy ;

eng: Black here and white there in patches.'
fr: noir ici et blanc la, par taches.'

eng: I have told the circumstances of the stranger's arrival in Iping with a certain fulness of detail, in order that the curious impression he created may be understood by the reader.
fr: J'ai rappele avec detail les circonstances de l'arrivee de l'etranger a Iping afin que le lecteur puisse comprendre la curiosite qu'excita cet homme.

eng: But excepting two odd incidents, the circumstances of his stay until the extraordinary day of the club festival may be passed over very cursorily.
fr: Mais, sauf deux incidents bizarres, son sejour, jusqu'a la fete du village, peut etre tres brievement raconte.

eng: There were a number of skirmishes with Mrs. Hall on matters of domestic discipline, but in every case until late April, when the first signs of penury began, he over-rode her by the easy expedient of an extra payment.
fr: Il y eut bien quelques escarmouches avec madame Hall a propos de questions domestiques ; cependant, chaque fois, jusqu'a la derniere dispute en avril, des qu'il voyait poindre les premiers symptomes de ladrerie, il lui imposait silence par l'expedient commode d'une forte indemnite.

eng: Hall did not like him, and whenever he dared he talked of the advisability of getting rid of him; but he showed his dislike chiefly by concealing it ostentatiously, and avoiding his visitor as much as possible.
fr: Hall n'aimait point son hote, et, toutes les fois qu'il l'osait, il parlait de la necessite de se debarrasser de lui ; mais il dissimulait son antipathie avec soin et le plus possible, evitait l'inconnu.

eng: 'He may be a bit overbearing, but bills settled punctual is bills settled punctual, whatever you d like to say.'
fr: 'Il est sans doute bien arrogant ; mais, il n'y a pas a dire, une note ponctuellement payee est une note ponctuellement payee.'

eng: 'The stranger did not go to church, and indeed made no difference between Sunday and the irreligious days, even in costume.'
fr: 'L'etranger n'assistait pas aux offices, et ne faisait aucune difference entre le dimanche et les jours de la semaine.'

eng: 'He worked, as Mrs. Hall thought, very fitfully.'
fr: 'Il travaillait, d'apres madame Hall, tres irregulierement.'

eng: His temper continued very uncertain;
fr: Son humeur demeurait tres inegale ;

eng: for the most part his manner was that of a man suffering under almost unendurable provocation, and once or twice things were snapped, torn, crushed, or broken in spasmodic gusts of violence.
fr: le plus souvent, ses manieres etaient d'une irritabilite presque insupportable ; souvent, des objets furent brises, dechires, ecrases, broyes dans des acces de violence.

eng: He seemed under a chronic irritation of the greatest intensity.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: His habit of talking to himself in a low voice grew steadily upon him, but though Mrs. Hall listened conscientiously she could make neither head nor tail of what she heard.
fr: Son habitude de se parler tout bas a lui-meme allait augmentant ; mais, quoique madame Hall ecoutat avec soin, elle ne pouvait trouver ni queue ni tete aux discours qu'elle entendait.

eng: He rarely went abroad by daylight, but at twilight he would go out muffled up invisibly, whether the weather were cold or not, and he chose the loneliest paths and those most overshadowed by trees and banks.
fr: Le voyageur paraissait rarement le jour ; mais, au crepuscule, il partait, bien enveloppe, la figure encapuchonnee, que le temps fut froid ou chaud, et il choisissait les chemins les plus solitaires et les plus ombrages ou les plus encaisses.

eng: His goggling spectacles and ghastly bandaged face under the penthouse of his hat, came with a disagreeable suddenness out of the darkness upon one or two home-going labourers,
fr: Ses gros yeux, dans son visage de spectre, sous le bord du chapeau, emergeaient soudain de l'obscurite, apparition desagreable pour les habitants qui rentraient au logis.

eng: and Teddy Henfrey, tumbling out of the "Scarlet Coat" one night, at half-past nine, was scared shamefully by the stranger s skull-like head (he was walking hat in hand) lit by the sudden light of the opened inn door.
fr: Teddy Henfrey, sortant vivement, un soir, a neuf heures et demie, de l'Habit Rouge, fut honteusement effraye par la tete de mort du voyageur (il se promenait le chapeau a la main) qu'une porte ouverte a l'improviste mit en pleine lumiere.

eng: It was inevitable that a person of so remarkable an appearance and bearing should form a frequent topic in such a village as Iping.
fr: Il etait inevitable que, dans un village comme Iping, un personnage d'allure si originale et de moeurs si singulieres fut souvent le sujet des conversations.

eng: Opinion was greatly divided about his occupation.
fr: Sur l'emploi de son temps, l'opinion etait tres divisee.

eng: Mrs. Hall was sensitive on the point.
fr: Madame Hall etait, sur ce point, tres susceptible.

eng: There was a song popular at that time called "The Bogey Man".
fr: Il y avait a cette epoque une chanson populaire intitulee le Croquemitaine :

eng: Miss Statchell sang it at the schoolroom concert (in aid of the church lamps), and thereafter whenever one or two of the villagers were gathered together and the stranger appeared, a bar or so of this tune, more or less sharp or flat, was whistled in the midst of them.
fr: miss Satchell l'avait chantee au concert de l'ecole -- au profit de l'eclairage du temple : depuis lors, toutes les fois que plusieurs villageois etaient reunis, si l'etranger venait a paraitre, les premieres mesures de cet air partaient du groupe, sifflees plus ou moins haut.

eng: Also belated little children would call "Bogey Man!" after him, and make off tremulously elated.
fr: Aussi, le soir, les enfants criaient-ils sur son chemin : << Croquemitaine ! Croquemitaine ! >> quitte a decamper aussitot, prudemment.

eng: Cuss, the general practitioner, was devoured by curiosity.
fr: Cuss, l'empirique du pays, etait devore par la curiosite.

eng: The bandages excited his professional interest, the report of the thousand and one bottles aroused his jealous regard.
fr: Les bandages excitaient son interet professionnel ; les mille et une bouteilles eveillaient sa jalousie.

eng: All through April and May he coveted an opportunity of talking to the stranger, and at last, towards Whitsuntide, he could stand it no longer, but hit upon the subscription-list for a village nurse as an excuse.
fr: Pendant tout avril et tout mai, il souhaita une occasion de parler a l'etranger ; enfin, aux environs de la Pentecote, n'y tenant plus, il imagina comme pretexte une liste de souscription en faveur d'une infirmiere communale.

eng: He was surprised to find that Mr. Hall did not know his guest s name.
fr: Il decouvrit alors avec etonnement que M. ~~~ Hall ignorait le nom de son hote.

eng: "He give a name," said Mrs. Hall an assertion which was quite unfounded "but I didn t rightly hear it."
fr: -- Il a donne un nom (affirmation tout a fait gratuite) mais je ne l'ai pas bien saisi -- declara madame Hall :

eng: She thought it seemed so silly not to know the man s name.
fr: tant il lui semblait bete de ne pas etre mieux renseignee.

eng: Cuss rapped at the parlour door and entered.
fr: Cuss frappa a la porte du salon et entra.

eng: There was a fairly audible imprecation from within.
fr: Un juron parfaitement net lui repondit de l'interieur.

eng: "Pardon my intrusion," said Cuss, and then the door closed and cut Mrs. Hall off from the rest of the conversation.
fr: -- Excusez mon importunite, dit Cuss. Puis la porte se referma, empechant madame Hall de saisir la suite de la conversation.

eng: She could hear the murmur of voices for the next ten minutes, then a cry of surprise, a stirring of feet, a chair flung aside, a bark of laughter, quick steps to the door, and Cuss appeared, his face white, his eyes staring over his shoulder.
fr: Dix minutes durant, elle percut le murmure des voix ; puis un cri de surprise, un remuement de pieds, la chute d'une chaise, un eclat de rire, des pas rapides, -- et Cuss reparut la face bleme, regardant par-dessus son epaule.

eng: He left the door open behind him, and without looking at her strode across the hall and went down the steps, and she heard his feet hurrying along the road.
fr: Il laissait la porte ouverte et, sans y faire attention, il passa en courant dans la grande salle et descendit les marches : elle entendit le bruit de sa course precipitee.

eng: He carried his hat in his hand.
fr: Il tenait son chapeau a la main.

eng: She stood behind the door, looking at the open door of the parlour.
fr: Elle restait debout derriere son comptoir, les yeux tournes vers le salon.

eng: Then she heard the stranger laughing quietly, and then his footsteps came across the room.
fr: L'etranger sourit tranquillement, puis ses pas traverserent la piece ;

eng: She could not see his face where she stood.
fr: mais elle ne put voir sa figure de l'endroit ou elle etait.

eng: '"That chap at the inn "
fr: '-- Cet individu de l'auberge...'

eng: "Well?"
fr: '-- Eh bien ?'

eng: "Give me something to drink," said Cuss, and he sat down.
fr: '-- Donnez-moi quelque chose a boire !... ~~~ continua Cuss. Et il s'assit.'

eng: When his nerves had been steadied by a glass of cheap sherry the only drink the good vicar had available he told him of the interview he had just had.
fr: '~~~ Quand ses nerfs furent calmes par un verre de sherry a bon marche, la seule boisson que put offrir le brave pasteur, il lui parla de la visite qu'il venait de faire.'

eng: "Went in," he gasped, "and began to demand a subscription for that Nurse Fund.
fr: '-- J'entrai, dit-il haletant, et je lui demandai son obole pour l'infirmiere que nous voulons avoir.'

eng: He d stuck his hands in his pockets as I came in, and he sat down lumpily in his chair.
fr: 'Il avait fourre ses mains dans ses poches ; il se laissa tomber lourdement sur sa chaise ;'

eng: Sniffed.
fr: 'il huma l'air.'

eng: I told him I d heard he took an interest in scientific things.
fr: '<< J'avais appris, ajoutai-je, qu'il s'interessait aux choses de la science. >>'

eng: He said yes.
fr: 'Il fit : << Oui >>,'

eng: Sniffed again.
fr: 'et il renifla de nouveau.'

eng: Kept on sniffing all the time; evidently recently caught an infernal cold.
fr: 'Il continua, d'ailleurs de renifler tout le temps : evidemment, il venait d'attraper un rhume infernal.'

eng: No wonder, wrapped up like that!
fr: 'Ce n'etait pas etonnant, vetu comme il l'etait...'

eng: I developed the nurse idea, and all the while kept my eyes open.
fr: 'Je debitai mon histoire d'infirmiere, en meme temps que j'observais :'

eng: Bottles chemicals everywhere.
fr: 'partout des bouteilles, des produits chimiques,'

eng: Balance, test-tubes in stands, and a smell of evening primrose.
fr: 'une balance, des eprouvettes ; dans l'air, une odeur de primevere.'

eng: Would he subscribe?
fr: 'Consentait-il a souscrire ?'

eng: Said he d consider it.
fr: 'Il repondit qu'il verrait.'

eng: Asked him, point-blank, was he researching.
fr: 'Alors, de but en blanc, je lui demandai s'il faisait des recherches.'

eng: Said he was.
fr: 'Il me dit que oui.'

eng: A long research?
fr: '<< Longues, ces recherches ? >>'

eng: Got quite cross.
fr: 'Le voila qui se fache :'

eng: A damnable long research, said he, blowing the cork out, so to speak.
fr: '<< Des recherches diablement longues ! >> clame-t-il comme s'il faisait explosion.'

eng: Oh, said I.
fr: '~~~ << Oh ! >> m'ecriai-je.'

eng: And out came the grievance.
fr: 'Voila l'origine de la scene.'

eng: The man was just on the boil, and my question boiled him over.
fr: 'Mon homme etait a bout de patience, ma question le fit eclater.'

eng: He had been given a prescription, most valuable prescription what for he wouldn t say.
fr: 'On lui avait donne une formule, formule extremement precieuse. Pour quoi faire ? Il ne voulait pas le dire.'

eng: Was it medical?
fr: 'Etait-ce une ordonnance ?'

eng: Damn you! What are you fishing after?
fr: '<< Que le diable vous emporte ! Melez-vous de vos affaires ! >>'

eng: I apologised.
fr: 'Je m'excuse.'

eng: Dignified sniff and cough.
fr: 'Il prend un air digne, tousse, renifle et se calme.'

eng: He resumed.
fr: 'Il va lire sa formule :'

eng: He d read it.
fr: '<< Cinq elements... >>'

eng: Five ingredients.
fr: 'Il la pose sur la table ; il tourne la tete.'

eng: Put it down; turned his head.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Draught of air from window lifted the paper.
fr: 'Un courant d'air venu de la fenetre souleve le papier.'

eng: Swish, rustle.
fr: 'Un souffle, un bruissement :'

eng: He was working in a room with an open fireplace, he said.
fr: 'Travailler dans une chambre avec une cheminee allumee ! >> dit-il.'

eng: Saw a flicker, and there was the prescription burning and lifting chimneyward.
fr: 'Je vois une lueur, et voila l'ordonnance qui prend feu et qui s'envole !'

eng: Rushed towards it just as it whisked up the chimney.
fr: 'Lui de se precipiter, au moment precis ou elle passait dans le tuyau.'

eng: So! Just at that point, to illustrate his story, out came his arm."
fr: 'Alors, dans son emotion, voila son bras qui sort...'

eng: "Well?"
fr: '-- Hein ? fit Bunting.'

eng: "No hand just an empty sleeve.
fr: '-- Pas de main ! Rien qu'une manche vide, Seigneur !'

eng: Lord! I thought, _that s_ a deformity!
fr: 'Je pensais : << C\'est une difformite. Il a, je suppose, un bras artificiel, et il l\'aura perdu. >>'

eng: Got a cork arm, I suppose, and has taken it off.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Then, I thought, there s something odd in that.
fr: 'Il y avait la, evidemment, quelque chose de singulier.'

eng: What the devil keeps that sleeve up and open, if there s nothing in it?
fr: 'Pourquoi diable cette manche reste-t-elle en l\'air, s\'il n\'y a rien dedans ?'

eng: There was nothing in it, I tell you.
fr: 'Et il n\'y avait rien dedans, vous dis-je.'

eng: Nothing down it, right down to the joint.
fr: 'Rien, rien, du haut en bas.'

eng: I could see right down it to the elbow, and there was a glimmer of light shining through a tear of the cloth.
fr: 'Mon regard plongeait jusqu\'a l\'epaule, et un peu de jour passait par une dechirure du vetement.'

eng: Good God! I said.
fr: '<< Bon Dieu ! >> m\'ecriai-je.'

eng: Then he stopped.
fr: 'Alors il s\'arreta.'

eng: Stared at me with those black goggles of his, and then at his sleeve."
fr: 'De ses gros yeux blancs a fleur de tete, il jeta un regard sur moi, puis sur sa manche.'

eng: "Well?"
fr: '-- Ensuite ?...'

eng: "That s all. He never said a word; just glared, and put his sleeve back in his pocket quickly.
fr: '-- C\'est tout. Il ne dit pas un mot. ~~~ Ses yeux brillerent et, rapidement, il enfonca la manche dans sa poche.'

eng: I was saying, said he, that there was the prescription burning, wasn t I?
fr: '<< Je disais donc, reprit-il, que ma formule brulait, n\'est-ce pas ? >>'

eng: Interrogative cough.
fr: 'Il poussa un grognement d\'interrogation.'

eng: How the devil, said I, can you move an empty sleeve like that?'
fr: '<< Mais comment diable, demandai-je, pouvez-vous remuer une manche vide ?'

eng: I stood up too.
fr: Je me levai aussi.

eng: He came towards me in three very slow steps, and stood quite close.
fr: En trois pas, il fut aupres de moi.

eng: Sniffed venomously.
fr: Il renifla mechamment.

eng: I didn't flinch, though I'm hanged if that bandaged knob of his, and those blinkers, aren't enough to unnerve any one, coming quietly up to you.
fr: Je ne bronchai point. Pourtant, je veux etre pendu si cette grosse boule, avec ses bandeaux et ses oeilleres, marchant sur vous tranquillement, n'avait pas de quoi faire perdre contenance a n'importe qui :

eng: "You said it was an empty sleeve?
fr: << -- Vous avez dit, je crois, continua-t-il, que c'etait une manche vide ?

eng: he said.
fr: - Oui, je l'ai dit. >>

eng: Certainly, I said.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: At staring and saying nothing a barefaced man, unspectacled, starts scratch.
fr: Moi, je recule epouvante devant cet energumene, la figure decouverte, sans lunettes, me devisageant.

eng: Then very quietly he pulled his sleeve out of his pocket again, and raised his arm towards me as though he would show it to me again.
fr: Tout doucement, il retire sa manche de sa poche et tend son bras vers moi, comme pour me le montrer de nouveau.

eng: He did it very, very slowly.
fr: Il fait cela tres, tres lentement.

eng: I looked at it.
fr: Je regardais.

eng: Seemed an age.
fr: Cela dure un siecle.

eng: "Well? said I, clearing my throat, there's nothing in it. "
fr: << Eh bien, -- repetai-je, faisant effort pour parler, -- il n'y a rien dedans ! >>

eng: "Had to say something.
fr: Il fallait bien dire quelque chose.

eng: I was beginning to feel frightened.
fr: Je commencais a avoir peur.

eng: I could see right down it.
fr: Je pouvais voir jusqu'au fond de sa manche ;

eng: He extended it straight towards me, slowly, slowly just like that until the cuff was six inches from my face.
fr: il l'avancait vers moi, lentement, lentement, comme ceci, jusqu'a six pouces de mon nez.

eng: Queer thing to see an empty sleeve come at you like that!
fr: C'est une chose etrange, allez, de voir une manche vide se tendre ainsi vers vous !

eng: "It's all very well for you to laugh, but I tell you I was so startled, I hit his cuff hard, and turned around, and cut out of the room I left him"
fr: 'C'est facile de rire ! ~~~ Mais je vous l'assure, j'etais si affole que je frappai violemment cette manche : je me retournai, je m'enfuis de la chambre, je le plantai la.'

eng: "Cuss stopped."
fr: 'Cuss s'arreta.'

eng: "There was no mistaking the sincerity of his panic."
fr: 'Il n'y avait pas a se meprendre sur la sincerite de sa terreur.'

eng: "He turned round in a helpless way and took a second glass of the excellent vicar's very inferior sherry."
fr: 'Il tournait sur lui-meme, dans un etat de grande faiblesse. Il but un second verre du mauvais sherry de l'excellent ministre.'

eng: ""When I hit his cuff," said Cuss, "I tell you, it felt exactly like hitting an arm.'"
fr: '-- Quand je frappai la manche, ce fut tout a fait comme si je touchais un bras.'

eng: Mr. Bunting thought it over.
fr: Bunting reflechit.

eng: He looked suspiciously at Cuss.
fr: Il regardait Cuss avec inquietude.

eng: "It s a most remarkable story," he said.
fr: -- C'est une histoire bien curieuse.

eng: He looked very wise and grave indeed.
fr: Il avait pris un air tres prudent et tres grave.

eng: "It s really," said Mr. Bunting with judicial emphasis, "a most remarkable story."
fr: -- En verite, -- repeta M. Bunting avec l'emphase d'un juge, -- c'est une histoire bien curieuse !

eng: She then distinctly heard the pad, pad, pad of bare feet coming out of the adjoining dressing-room and walking along the passage towards the staircase.
fr: Elle distingua alors le sourd poum, poum, poum de pieds dechausses, sortant du cabinet de toilette contigu et suivant le corridor dans la direction de l'escalier.

eng: As soon as she felt assured of this, she aroused the Rev. Mr. Bunting as quietly as possible.
fr: Des qu'elle en fut bien sure, elle secoua le plus doucement possible le reverend M. Bunting.

eng: He did not strike a light, but putting on his spectacles, her dressing-gown and his bath slippers, he went out on the landing to listen.
fr: Il ne frotta point d'allumette. Il mit ses besicles. Il passa la robe de chambre de sa femme, il enfila ses pantoufles et alla sur le palier pour ecouter.

eng: He heard quite distinctly a fumbling going on at his study desk down-stairs, and then a violent sneeze.
fr: Il entendit tres bien remuer en bas, dans son bureau. Puis, un eternuement sonore.

eng: At that he returned to his bedroom, armed himself with the most obvious weapon, the poker, and descended the staircase as noiselessly as possible.
fr: Il rentra dans sa chambre, se munit de la premiere arme qui lui tomba sous la main, le tisonnier, et descendit l'escalier en prenant mille precautions.

eng: Mrs. Bunting came out on the landing.
fr: Madame Bunting resta sur le carre.

eng: The hour was about four, and the ultimate darkness of the night was past.
fr: Il etait environ quatre heures du matin : ce n'etait deja plus la profonde obscurite de la nuit.

eng: Everything was still except the faint creaking of the stairs under Mr. Bunting s tread, and the slight movements in the study.
fr: D'ailleurs, silence absolu ; rien que le leger craquement des marches sous les pas de M. Bunting et, dans le cabinet, de vagues bruits.

eng: Then something snapped, the drawer was opened, and there was a rustle of papers.
fr: Alors un tiroir fut ouvert, on percut un froissement de papiers.

eng: Then came an imprecation, and a match was struck and the study was flooded with yellow light.
fr: Puis un juron, une allumette frottee, et la piece fut eclairee d'une lumiere blonde.

eng: Mr. Bunting was now in the hall, and through the crack of the door he could see the desk and the open drawer and a candle burning on the desk.
fr: M. Bunting etait a ce moment dans le vestibule et, a travers la fente de la porte, il pouvait voir le tiroir ouvert et une bougie allumee.

eng: But the robber he could not see.
fr: Mais le voleur, il ne l'apercevait point.

eng: One thing kept Mr. Bunting's courage; the persuasion that this burglar was a resident in the village.
fr: Une consideration leur donna du courage : la conviction que le cambrioleur etait un habitant du village.

eng: They heard the chink of money, and realised that the robber had found the housekeeping reserve of gold two pounds ten in half sovereigns altogether.
fr: Ils entendirent un tintement ; ils comprirent que le voleur avait trouve leur reserve pour les depenses du menage, en tout deux livres et demie.

eng: At that sound Mr. Bunting was nerved to abrupt action.
fr: Cela decida M. Bunting a brusquer les choses

eng: Gripping the poker firmly, he rushed into the room, closely followed by Mrs. Bunting.
fr: ayant assure le tisonnier dans sa main, il s'avanca suivi de pres par madame Bunting.

eng: "Surrender!" cried Mr. Bunting, fiercely, and then stooped amazed.
fr: -- Rendez-vous ! cria-t-il avec colere.

eng: Apparently the room was perfectly empty.
fr: Mais il s'arreta stupefait : la piece semblait parfaitement vide.

eng: For half a minute, perhaps, they stood gaping,
fr: Pendant une demi-minute peut-etre, ils resterent ebahis ;

eng: then Mrs. Bunting went across the room and looked behind the screen,
fr: puis madame Bunting traversa le cabinet et regarda derriere le paravent,

eng: while Mr. Bunting, by a kindred impulse, peered under the desk.
fr: tandis que son mari, par une inspiration semblable, regardait sous le bureau.

eng: Then Mrs. Bunting turned back the window-curtains,
fr: Madame Bunting secoua les rideaux de la fenetre.

eng: and Mr. Bunting looked up the chimney and probed it with the poker.
fr: M. Bunting inspecta la cheminee, l'explorant avec son tisonnier ;

eng: Then Mrs. Bunting scrutinised the waste-paper basket
fr: l'un fouilla la corbeille a papiers,

eng: and Mr. Bunting opened the lid of the coal-scuttle.
fr: l'autre le seau a charbon.

eng: Then they came to a stop and stood with eyes interrogating each other.
fr: Enfin ils finirent par s'arreter et demeurerent confondus, s'interrogeant mutuellement des yeux.

eng: "I could have sworn " said Mr. Bunting.
fr: -- J'aurais pourtant jure..., fit madame Bunting.

eng: "The candle!"
fr: -- Mais la bougie !

eng: "And the money's gone!" She went hastily to the doorway.
fr: 'Et l'argent a disparu ! Elle se precipita vers la porte.

eng: "Of all the strange occurrences..."
fr: '-- C'est bien la le cas le plus extraordinaire...

eng: There was a violent sneeze in the passage.
fr: Il y eut un formidable eternuement dans le corridor.

eng: They rushed out, and as they did so the kitchen door slammed.
fr: Ils y coururent. Au meme instant, la porte de la cuisine battit avec violence.

eng: "Bring the candle," said Mr. Bunting, and led the way.
fr: -- Apportez la bougie ! ordonna M. Bunting. Et il s'avanca.

eng: They both heard a sound of bolts being hastily shot back.
fr: Il y eut un bruit de verrou rapidement repousse.

eng: As he opened the kitchen door he saw through the scullery that the back door was just opening, and the faint light of early dawn displayed the dark masses of the garden beyond.
fr: Comme il arrivait a l'entree de la cuisine, le pasteur vit que la porte de l'office s'ouvrait egalement et que les premieres lueurs de l'aurore baignaient les masses sombres du jardin.

eng: He is certain that nothing went out of the door.
fr: Il etait certain que personne n'etait sorti par la.

eng: It opened, stood open for a moment, and then closed with a slam.
fr: Pourtant la porte s'ouvrit, resta ouverte un moment, puis se referma bruyamment.

eng: As it did so, the candle Mrs. Bunting was carrying from the study flickered and flared.
fr: En meme temps, la bougie que madame Bunting avait apportee du cabinet tremblota et jeta un eclat plus vif.

eng: It was a minute or more before they entered the kitchen.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The place was empty.
fr: La cuisine etait deserte.

eng: They refastened the back door, examined the kitchen, pantry, and scullery thoroughly, and at last went down into the cellar.
fr: Ils visiterent a fond le garde-manger, l'office, et enfin descendirent a la cave.

eng: There was not a soul to be found in the house, search as they would.
fr: Ils eurent beau chercher : personne dans toute la maison.

eng: Daylight found the vicar and his wife, a quaintly-costumed little couple, still marvelling about on their own ground floor by the unnecessary light of a guttering candle.
fr: Le jour surprit le pasteur et sa femme, au rez-de-chaussee, tous deux bizarrement accoutres, continuant a ne rien comprendre, eclaires par la lumiere bien inutile d'une bougie qui coulait.

eng: CHAPTER VI. THE FURNITURE THAT WENT MAD
fr: VI LE MOBILIER QUI DANSE

eng: Now it happened that in the early hours of Whit Monday, before Millie was hunted out for the day, Mr. Hall and Mrs. Hall both rose and went noiselessly down into the cellar.
fr: Or, aux premieres heures de ce meme lundi de la Pentecote, avant que Millie ait ete tiree de son grabat par le jour, M. et madame Hall descendirent a la cave.

eng: Their business there was of a private nature, and had something to do with the specific gravity of their beer.
fr: Affaire d'ordre prive : il s'agissait de baptiser leur biere.

eng: They had hardly entered the cellar when Mrs. Hall found she had forgotten to bring down a bottle of sarsaparilla from their joint-room.
fr: Ils y etaient a peine quand madame Hall s'apercut qu'elle avait oublie d'apporter une bouteille de salsepareille.

eng: As she was the expert and principal operator in this affair, Hall very properly went upstairs for it.
fr: Comme c'etait elle qui officiait, Hall fut la prendre.

eng: On the landing he was surprised to see that the stranger's door was ajar.
fr: Sur le palier, il fut surpris de voir entre-baillee la porte de l'etranger.

eng: He went on into his own room and found the bottle as he had been directed.
fr: Il entra dans sa chambre, a lui, et trouva la bouteille a la place indiquee.

eng: But returning with the bottle, he noticed that the bolts of the front door had been shot back, that the door was in fact simply on the latch.
fr: Mais, en revenant, il observa que la porte d'entree n'etait plus verrouillee.

eng: And with a flash of inspiration he connected this with the stranger's room upstairs and the suggestions of Mr. Teddy Henfrey.
fr: Dans une lueur soudaine d'intelligence, il fit un rapprochement entre ce fait, la chambre de l'etranger ouverte, la-haut, et les hypotheses de Teddy Henfrey.

eng: He distinctly remembered holding the candle while Mrs. Hall shot these bolts overnight.
fr: Il se souvenait cependant, et tres nettement, d'avoir tenu la bougie pour eclairer madame Hall lorsque, le soir, elle avait pousse les verrous.

eng: At the sight he stopped, gaping, then with the bottle still in his hand went upstairs again.
fr: Il s'arreta, au comble de l'ahurissement ; puis, sa bouteille a la main, il remonta l'escalier.

eng: He rapped at the stranger's door.
fr: Il frappa chez l'etranger : pas de reponse.

eng: There was no answer.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text, implied in previous sentence)

eng: He rapped again; then pushed the door wide open and entered.
fr: Ayant frappe de nouveau, il entra.

eng: It was as he expected.
fr: Comme il s'y attendait,

eng: The bed, the room also, was empty.
fr: vide le lit, vide la chambre !

eng: And what was stranger, even to his heavy intelligence, on the bedroom chair and along the rail of the bed were scattered the garments, the only garments so far as he knew, and the bandages of their guest.
fr: Et, chose inouie, sur la chaise et sur le bord du lit etaient en desordre les vetements de l'hote, les seuls vetements qu'on lui eut jamais vus, ainsi que ses bandeaux.

eng: "George! You gart whad a wand?"
fr: '-- George ! Tu as trouve ?

eng: At that he turned and hurried down to her.
fr: A cet appel, il tressaillit et sortit precipitamment.

eng: "Janny," he said, over the rail of the cellar steps, " tas the truth what Henfrey sez. E s not in uz room, e en t. And the front door s onbolted."
fr: ~~~ lui dit-il par-dessus la rampe de l'escalier, c'est vrai ce que disait Henfrey !... Il n'est pas dans sa chambre, il n'y est pas. Et la porte de la rue n'est plus verrouillee.

eng: At first Mrs. Hall did not understand, and as soon as she did she resolved to see the empty room for herself.
fr: D'abord madame Hall ne comprit pas ; mais, des qu'elle eut saisi, elle voulut voir par elle-meme la chambre vide.

eng: Hall, still holding the bottle, went first.
fr: Hall, tenant toujours sa bouteille, commenca par redescendre jusqu'en bas.

eng: "If e en t there," he said, " is close are. And what s e doin ithout is close, then? Tas a most curious business."
fr: -- S'il n'y est pas, ses vetements y sont. Et que peut-il faire sans ses vetements ? Ma foi, c'est bien singulier.

eng: As they came up the cellar steps they both, it was afterwards ascertained, fancied they heard the front door open and shut, but seeing it closed and nothing there, neither said a word to the other about it at the time.
fr: Comme ils remontaient, tous deux - ce fut reconnu exact par la suite -, ils crurent entendre la porte de la rue s'ouvrir et se refermer ; pourtant, la voyant close (rien n'apparaissait d'anormal), ni l'un ni l'autre, a ce moment-la, n'en dit un mot.

eng: Mrs. Hall passed her husband in the passage and ran on first upstairs.
fr: Madame Hall depassa son mari dans le corridor et arriva en haut la premiere.

eng: Someone sneezed on the staircase.
fr: Quelqu'un eternua dans l'escalier :

eng: Hall, following six steps behind, thought that he heard her sneeze. She, going on first, was under the impression that Hall was sneezing.
fr: Hall, qui suivait a six pas, crut que c'etait sa femme ; elle, etant au-dessus, s'imagina que c'etait lui.

eng: She flung open the door and stood regarding the room.
fr: Elle poussa violemment la porte et s'arreta sur le seuil de la chambre.

eng: "Of all the curious!" she said.
fr: << Ah bien ! ~~~ en voila une affaire ! >> s'ecria-t-elle.
